compute_chieff(m1, m2, chi1, chi2, cos_theta_1, cos_theta_2)[source]

Compute the effective spin of each binaries. :param : :type : param m1 (np.1darray): Array containing the masses of the first component. :param : :type : param m2 (np.1darray): Array containing the masses of the second component. :param : :type : param chi1 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the first components. :param : :type : param chi2 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the second components. :param : :type : param cos_theta_1 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the first components. :param : :type : param cos_theta_2 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the second components. :param : :type : return (np.1darray): Array with the effective spin of each binaries.

Parameters:

  • m1 (ndarray)

  • m2 (ndarray)

  • chi1 (ndarray)

  • chi2 (ndarray)

  • cos_theta_1 (ndarray)

  • cos_theta_2 (ndarray)

Return type:

ndarray

compute_chip(m1, m2, chi1, chi2, cos_theta_1, cos_theta_2)[source]

Compute the precessing spin of each binaries. :param : :type : param m1 (np.1darray): Array containing the masses of the first component. :param : :type : param m2 (np.1darray): Array containing the masses of the second component. :param : :type : param chi1 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the first components. :param : :type : param chi2 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the second components. :param : :type : param cos_theta_1 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the first components. :param : :type : param cos_theta_2 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the second components. :param : :type : return (np.1darray): Array with the precessing spin of each binaries.

compute_spins(chi1, chi2, costheta1, costheta2)[source]

Compute spins of the two components s_i = chi_i*costheta_i :param : :type : param chi1 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the first components. :param : :type : param chi2 (np.1darray): Array containing the magnitudes of the second components. :param : :type : param costheta1 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the first components. :param : :type : param costheta2 (np.1darray): Array containing the theta cosine of the second components. :param : components. :type : return: tuple containing two np.1darray s1(s2) is the projection on the z axis of the spin for firts(seconds)

Parameters:

  • chi1 (ndarray)

  • chi2 (ndarray)

  • costheta1 (ndarray)

  • costheta2 (ndarray)

Return type:

tuple

generate_spin(size)[source]

Generate spin magnitude and theta angle from the model set by the user : self.spin_option. :param : :type : param size (int): size of the catalog. :param : :type : return: tuple of np.array chi1, chi2, costheta1, costheta2

Parameters:

size (int)

Return type:

tuple

classmethod load(model_path)[source]

Loads a previously saved AstroModel instance from a pickle file. If the loaded object is a dictionary, it converts it back into an AstroModel instance.

make_catalog()[source]

Create a catalog with the appropriate parameters for further calculations. The catalog will be named after the parameter self.name and saved in the folder Catalogs/.

save()[source]

Saves the current AstroModel instance to a pickle file for later use.

catalogue_generation

generate_population(num_sources, mass_method='m1_m2', mass_distribution='uniform', z_distribution='uniform', mass_params=None, z_params=None)[source]

Generate a binary system population with given distributions.

Parameters: - num_sources (int): Number of binary systems to generate. - mass_method (str): ‘m1_m2’ for primary and secondary mass, ‘chirp_q’ for chirp mass and mass ratio. - mass_distribution (str): ‘uniform’ or ‘gaussian’ for mass parameters. - z_distribution (str): ‘uniform’ or ‘gaussian’ for redshift. - mass_params (dict): Parameters for mass distribution. - z_params (dict): Parameters for redshift distribution.

Returns: - pd.DataFrame: Generated population.

sample_distribution(distribution, size, **kwargs)[source]

Generate samples from a given distribution.

Parameters: - distribution (str): Type of distribution (‘uniform’ or ‘gaussian’). - size (int): Number of samples. - kwargs: Parameters for the chosen distribution.

Returns: - np.array: Generated samples.

save_population(population_df, filename)[source]

Save the generated population to a .dat file using Pandas.

Parameters: - population_df (pd.DataFrame): Population data. - filename (str): Output file name.

SNR_source(mtot, z, q, waveform_approx)[source]

TEST FUNCTION USE ONLY FOR TESTS Compute the snr of one specific source, assuming spins are 0 and the best sky location. :param : :type : param mtot (float): Total mass of the system in Msun. :param : :type : param z (float): Redshift of the merger. :param : :type : param q (float): Mass ratio of the system. By convention q<1. :param : :type : param waveform_approx (str): Waveform to use for the computation of the SNR. :param : :type : return (snr): Signal-to-noise ration of the soure in the detector.

Parameters:

  • mtot (float)

  • z (float)

  • q (float)

  • waveform_approx (str)

Return type:

float

Evaluates the trained model’s performance by: - Comparing predictions against true SNR values. - Generating scatter plots highlighting errors. - Saving a performance report.

train_model_if_needed()[source]

Checks if a pre-trained model exists. If not, it generates a training dataset, trains a Random Forest model, and evaluates its performance.

reshape_pic(delimiter='\t', Header=False, index=False)[source]

Reshape your psd to fit the Make psd function and write it in a new file in AuxiliaryFiles/PSDs. It also uptate the variable psd_file to the new directory. :param : :type : param delimiter (str): delimiter used in the original file. Default is ‘ ‘. :param : :type : param Header (bool): True if the original file contain a header. Default is False. :param : :type : param index (bool): True if the original file contain a column with indexes. Default is False.

Parameters:

  • delimiter (str)

  • Header (bool)

  • index (bool)

waveform

GWk_no_ecc_pycbcwf(evt, freq, approx, n, size_catalogue, inc_option='InCat', disable_progress_bar=False)[source]

This function calculates the contribution of a binary.

Parameters:

  • evt (pandas.Series) – Given event from the re-built catalogue.

  • freq (numpy.array) – Observed frequency range for the calculation.

  • approx (str) – Waveform approximant.

  • n (int) – Index of the event in the catalogue.

  • size_catalogue (int) – Total number of events in the catalogue.

  • inc_option (str, optional) – Inclination handling mode (‘InCat’, ‘Rand’, ‘Optimal’).

Returns:

htildSQ – Contribution of the source to each observed frequency, or 0 if outside range.

Return type:

numpy.array or int

snr

SNR_catalog(catalog_name, det_list, waveform, freq)[source]

Computes the optimal Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) for each event in the catalog and saves the updated catalog with additional SNR columns.

Parameters:

  • det_list (list) – List of Detector objects used for SNR computation.

  • waveform (str) – The waveform model used for gravitational wave signal generation.

  • freq (np.array) – Frequency array used for the SNR computation.

  • catalog_name (str)

Notes

  • If an event produces an invalid htildsq value, it is logged in an error file.

  • The function modifies and saves the catalog with SNR values for each detector.

SNR_pycbc_catalog(catalog_name, det_list, waveform, catalogue_path=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • catalog_name (str)

  • det_list (list)

  • waveform (str)

SNR_single(event, det_list, network, waveform, freq, savefile=False, name='event')[source]

Computes the optimal Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) for a single event using a list of detectors.

The function calculates the SNR for each detector in the list and combines them for the given network. If requested, the results are saved in a .dat file.

Parameters:

  • event (dict) – Dictionary containing the event parameters, including ‘m1’, ‘m2’, ‘z’, and ‘Dl’.

  • det_list (list) – List of Detector objects used for SNR computation.

  • network (Network) – The network of detectors for combining SNRs.

  • waveform (str) – The waveform model used for gravitational wave signal generation.

  • freq (np.array) – Frequency array used for the SNR computation.

  • savefile (bool, optional) – If True, saves the SNR results to a file (default is False).

  • name (str, optional) – Name of the event, used for the output filename (default is ‘event’).

Returns:

Series containing the combined SNR for the specified network.

Return type:

pd.Series

Notes

  • If an event produces an invalid htildsq value, it is logged in an error file.

  • The function modifies and saves the catalog with SNR values for each detector.

  • The function checks if required keys (‘m1’, ‘m2’, ‘z’, ‘Dl’) are present in the event.

combine_snr_detectors(det_list, net, SNRs, savefile=False, name='event')[source]

Combines the SNRs from multiple detectors for a given network.

The function calculates the optimal and network SNRs by summing the squares of the individual detector contributions. A random factor from the factor table is used to simulate different configurations.

Parameters:

  • det_list (list) – List of Detector objects.

  • net (str) – Name of the network (e.g., ‘HLV’, ‘ET’).

  • SNRs (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing the individual SNRs for each detector.

  • savefile (bool, optional) – If True, saves the combined SNR results to a file (default is False).

  • name (str, optional) – Name of the event, used for the output filename (default is ‘event’).

Returns:

Updated DataFrame containing the combined SNRs for the network.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

FileNotFoundError – If ‘factor_table.dat’ is not found in ‘AuxiliaryFiles/’.

Notes

  • This function uses a factor table to apply configuration-specific corrections.

  • It computes both optimal and realistic SNRs for the network.

compute_SNR_Networks_catalog(catalog_name)[source]
Parameters:

catalog_name (str)

class background

class Background[source]

Bases: object

Analysis()[source]

Performs the analysis for each astrophysical model catalog. Computes Omega at specified frequencies and SNR for each network and its thresholds. Updates the analysis dictionary with the results.

Analysis_noResidual(Networks)[source]
Make_Ana_Output()[source]

Initializes the analysis output structure. Creates a DataFrame for each catalog, containing results for ‘Total’ and each network with its respective SNR thresholds.

Network_list()[source]

Initializes the network list.

Omega_ecc(cat)[source]
Omega_pycbc()[source]

Computes the Omega function using the pycbc waveform model for all events in the AstroModel catalogs. Saves the results in the appropriate results folder.

Write_results()[source]
compute_Omega()[source]

background snr

SNR_Net_wf(cat, Net)[source]
SNR_Omega(freq, Omega, Networks)[source]

Calculate the SNR of a given spectrum Omega for each Network in Networks. Assuming one year of detection with a duty-cycle (ie. efficiency) of 0.5

SNR_bkg(freq_omg, Omega, Network)[source]

Computes the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for a stochastic gravitational wave background.

Parameters:

  • freq_omg (numpy.ndarray) – Array of input frequencies for Omega.

  • Omega (numpy.ndarray) – Normalized spectral energy density of the stochastic background.

  • Network (object) – Detector network containing frequency and composition information.

Returns:

Computed SNR value.

Return type:

float

SNR_bkg_1det(freq_omg, Omega, Network)[source]

Old function for SNR background computation :param freq_omg: :param Omega: :param Network: :return:

SNR_bkgtrash(freq_omg, Omega, Network)[source]

Old function to compute the background :param freq_omg: :param Omega: :param Network: :return:

SNR_run(SNR_0, SNR_year, duration, tstart)[source]
Parameters:

  • SNR_0 – Starting SNR (SNR at the end of a previous run for example)

  • SNR_year – SNR for one year of observation (careful to know what the duty-cycle is at this point)

  • duration – duration of the run in yr

  • tstart – starting time

Returns:

dataframe with two columns ‘Time’ and ‘SNR’
